Question: What should we name the Discord server? (e.g., Lewis HQ, Home Base, The Bridge)
Why This Matters: You'll see this name every day. It should feel like yours, not like a tech project.
Our Recommendation: Something personal ‚Äî 'Lewis HQ' or 'Home Base' feel right. Avoid anything that sounds like a work Slack.

Question: Do you want separate channels per topic (#shopping, #budget, #tasks, #goals) or fewer combined channels?
Why This Matters: More channels = more organized but can feel overwhelming. Fewer channels = simpler but noisier.
Our Recommendation: Start with 5-6 focused channels. You can always merge or split later. Too few channels means important things get buried.

Question: Should the bot respond in the same channel you message it, or should responses go to a dedicated #bot-responses channel?
Why This Matters: In-channel feels conversational. Separate channel keeps things clean but adds friction to read responses.
Our Recommendation: In-channel. Conversation should feel natural, not like submitting a ticket.

Question: Do you want a private DM channel with the bot for personal things (individual goals, private budget questions)?
Why This Matters: Some things you might not want in shared channels ‚Äî personal habit check-ins, individual spending, etc.
Our Recommendation: Yes. The bot should respond to DMs as well as channel messages. Shared stuff in channels, personal stuff in DMs.

Question: Should the bot post in #logs every time it takes an action (full transparency)?
Why This Matters: Transparency builds trust ‚Äî you can always see what the bot did. But it can be noisy.
Our Recommendation: Yes, but make it a channel you can mute. Transparency matters early on while you're learning to trust the system.

Question: What channels should have notifications enabled vs. muted by default?
Why This Matters: Discord notification fatigue is real. If everything pings, nothing matters.
Our Recommendation: Only #command and #shopping should ping. Everything else (briefs, budget, logs) should be muted by default ‚Äî check when you want to.

Question: How do you currently manage your shopping list? (Shared note, app, paper, texting each other?)
Why This Matters: Understanding current workflow tells us what friction to eliminate. Don't replace something that works.
Our Recommendation: Whatever you do now, the bot should be strictly easier. If texting 'add milk' to a Discord channel isn't faster than your current method, we've failed.

Question: Should both of you be able to add items, or does one person usually manage the list?
Why This Matters: Determines whether the bot needs to track who added what and whether both get notifications.
Our Recommendation: Both should be able to add. The bot should say who added what so there's no confusion.

Question: Do you want the bot to remind you of recurring staples? (e.g., 'You usually buy milk every 10 days ‚Äî need more?')
Why This Matters: Smart reminders reduce forgotten items but can feel naggy if overdone.
Our Recommendation: Yes, but only after 3+ purchase cycles of data. Don't guess ‚Äî learn patterns first, then suggest.

Question: Do you shop at multiple stores? Should items be grouped by store?
Why This Matters: If you split shopping across Costco/grocery/specialty, grouping by store saves time in the aisle.
Our Recommendation: Support it but don't require it. Simple 'add eggs' should just work without specifying a store.

Question: When an item is checked off, should it disappear or stay visible as 'done'?
Why This Matters: Some people like seeing what's been gotten (especially if splitting the shopping trip). Others want a clean list.
Our Recommendation: Stay visible as checked off during the trip, auto-clear 24 hours after the last item is checked.

Question: How comfortable are you with linking bank accounts to an automated system?
Why This Matters: Plaid is secure (used by Venmo, Robinhood, etc.) but some people have valid concerns about connecting bank data.
Our Recommendation: Plaid is industry standard and read-only ‚Äî it cannot move money or make transactions. But both of you should be comfortable before we connect real accounts.

Question: Do you want per-category budgets (dining: $500, groceries: $600) or just total monthly tracking?
Why This Matters: Per-category gives more control but requires more setup. Total spend is simpler but less actionable.
Our Recommendation: Start with 5-6 major categories (dining, groceries, gas, subscriptions, household, discretionary). You can add more later.

Question: Should the bot alert you when you're approaching a budget limit? At what threshold?
Why This Matters: Proactive alerts prevent overspending but can feel judgmental if badly timed.
Our Recommendation: Alert at 75% and 90% of monthly budget. Post to #budget channel, not DM ‚Äî spending is a household topic.

Question: Should spending data be fully shared, or do you each want some private spending visibility?
Why This Matters: Full transparency is great for shared budgets but some personal spending privacy is healthy.
Our Recommendation: Have an honest conversation about this. Our recommendation: shared view for joint accounts, individual discretionary spending is private unless you both want it shared.

Question: How often do you want budget summaries? Daily, weekly, or only when asked?
Why This Matters: Daily can feel like micromanagement. Weekly might miss overspending in real-time.
Our Recommendation: Weekly summary every Sunday evening. Mid-week alert only if you're trending over budget. Daily is too much.

Question: What time should the morning brief post? What time zone?
Why This Matters: Too early = ignored. Too late = useless. Should land when you're actually starting your day.
Our Recommendation: 7:00 AM local time on weekdays, 9:00 AM on weekends. Adjust after a week of use.

Question: What should be in the morning brief? (Calendar, tasks, habits, weather, budget, all of it?)
Why This Matters: The brief should be glanceable ‚Äî 30 seconds to read. Too much info defeats the purpose.
Our Recommendation: Calendar + today's tasks + habit check-ins due + weather. Budget only if there's an alert. Keep it under 15 lines.

Question: Should there be an evening check-in? What should it ask?
Why This Matters: Evening nudges help close the loop on habits and tasks but can feel annoying after a long day.
Our Recommendation: Yes, but gentle. 'You have 2 unchecked habits today ‚Äî want to log them?' Not 'You failed to complete your habits.'

Question: Should Lenale get the same brief as Parker, or a customized version?
Why This Matters: You probably have different priorities. Parker may care about goals/habits. Lenale may care about calendar/shopping.
Our Recommendation: Customized. Each person should configure what shows up in their brief via a simple 'my brief includes...' command.

Question: Should the bot assign tasks to a specific person, or are tasks shared?
Why This Matters: If tasks are personal, you each see your own. If shared, you need assignment and visibility into who's doing what.
Our Recommendation: Support both. Default is shared/unassigned. Either person can claim or assign. The bot should know who's responsible.

Question: How should the bot handle overdue tasks? Nag? Escalate? Silently reschedule?
Why This Matters: Nagging is annoying but effective. Silent rescheduling hides problems. Need the right balance.
Our Recommendation: One reminder the day it's due, one nudge the day after. After 3 days overdue, ask 'Should I reschedule this or is it still happening?' No more than that.

Question: Should the bot be able to create tasks from context? (e.g., 'Email from dentist = create dentist appointment task')
Why This Matters: Automatic task creation from email/calendar is powerful but can create noise if it guesses wrong.
Our Recommendation: Not yet. Start with explicit task creation only. Add smart suggestions later once the core loop is trusted.

Question: Should Lenale have her own goals and habits, or is this Parker-only for now?
Why This Matters: If the system is household-wide, Lenale should be able to track her own things too.
Our Recommendation: Both. Personal goals are private by default. Either person can share a goal to a channel if they want accountability.

Question: How aggressive should habit nudges be? (Gentle reminder vs. 'You haven't done X in 3 days')
Why This Matters: Too soft = ignored. Too aggressive = resented. Tone matters enormously here.
Our Recommendation: Start gentle. The bot should never make you feel bad. 'Hey, want to check in on meditation today?' not 'You've missed meditation 3 days in a row.' Escalate tone only if explicitly asked to.

Question: Should the bot celebrate streaks and milestones? How?
Why This Matters: Positive reinforcement works. But if it feels fake or excessive it gets annoying fast.
Our Recommendation: Yes, but sparingly. Celebrate 7-day, 30-day, and 100-day streaks. A simple 'üî• 7-day meditation streak!' in the relevant channel. No essays.

Question: Should the bot have a name?
Why This Matters: A name makes it feel like a household member vs. a tool. Some people love it, some find it cringe.
Our Recommendation: Give it a name. It lives in your Discord. 'Starbase' works, or pick something fun together. A named bot feels more natural to talk to.

Question: What tone should the bot use? (Formal, casual, playful, minimal?)
Why This Matters: If the tone feels wrong, people stop using it. This is the #1 reason chatbots get abandoned.
Our Recommendation: Casual but competent. Like a very organized friend, not a corporate assistant. Short sentences. No exclamation marks on everything.

Question: Should the bot use emoji?
Why This Matters: Emoji can make messages scannable and friendly, or feel childish depending on taste.
Our Recommendation: Light emoji for status indicators (‚úÖ, ‚ö†Ô∏è, üî•) and channel-appropriate reactions. Not every message needs emoji.

Question: When the bot doesn't understand a request, how should it respond?
Why This Matters: Bad error handling kills trust fast. 'I don't understand' with no guidance is frustrating.
Our Recommendation: Be honest and helpful: 'I'm not sure what you mean. Did you want me to [best guess A] or [best guess B]?' Always offer options, never just fail.

Question: Should Lenale have the same level of access as Parker, or are some things admin-only?
Why This Matters: Equal access = full partnership. Tiered access = one person controls the system. Both are valid.
Our Recommendation: Equal access to all shared features. Parker retains admin for system configuration (adding integrations, changing bot behavior). This isn't about trust ‚Äî it's about not accidentally breaking things.

Question: Should the bot remember and reference personal context? (e.g., 'You mentioned you were stressed about work on Monday')
Why This Matters: Context-awareness makes the agent more helpful but some people find it unsettling.
Our Recommendation: Yes for factual context (appointments, tasks, goals). No for emotional context ‚Äî the bot shouldn't play therapist.

Question: Who can add new integrations or change the bot's behavior?
Why This Matters: If either person can reconfigure the system, changes might surprise the other.
Our Recommendation: Parker manages integrations and system config. Either person can customize their own brief and notification preferences. Changes to shared channels require a heads-up to the other person.

Question: How should you submit feedback? (Dedicated command, dedicated channel, DM to bot?)
Why This Matters: The easier it is to give feedback, the more feedback you'll get. The more feedback, the faster the system improves.
Our Recommendation: All three. Say 'feedback: [thing]' anywhere ‚Äî in a channel, in a DM, as a command. The bot captures it and posts to #feedback for visibility.

Question: Should the bot ask for feedback proactively? (e.g., 'You haven't used shopping in 2 weeks ‚Äî is it working for you?')
Why This Matters: Proactive feedback prompts surface problems early. But they're annoying if too frequent.
Our Recommendation: Yes, but maximum once per week, and only about features that seem underused. Easy to dismiss with a 'it's fine' response.

Question: How should improvement requests get prioritized?
Why This Matters: Without prioritization, feedback becomes a graveyard of unread requests.
Our Recommendation: The bot categorizes (bug, feature, improvement) and the weekly review surfaces the top items. Parker makes the final call on what gets built next.

Question: What's the first thing you want to be able to do with the bot on Day 1?
Why This Matters: First impression matters. If the first interaction is confusing, adoption dies.
Our Recommendation: Shopping list management. It's shared, it's daily, and 'add milk to the list' is dead simple. Win her over with the easiest feature first.

Question: How much setup are you willing to do before the bot is useful?
Why This Matters: Some systems require hours of configuration. Others work out of the box. Know your tolerance.
Our Recommendation: Near zero. The bot should work with sensible defaults from Day 1. Configuration should be optional and incremental ‚Äî not a prerequisite.

Question: Would a guided tour be helpful, or do you prefer to just start using it?
Why This Matters: Some people learn by reading instructions. Others learn by doing.
Our Recommendation: Just start using it. The bot should handle 'help' and 'what can you do?' commands naturally. No mandatory walkthrough.
